q: Older workers are hard to train
Older workers do not want to train
Older workers are not economical to train
Older workers do not get good training outcomes
Older workers are too close to retirement
Older workers are too cautious
Older workers are skilled
Older workers are productive employees
Older workers cannot easily adapt to new technology
Older workers are quick to absorb new knowledge
Older workers are disruptive in team meetings
Older workers dislike taking orders from younger workers
Older workers have poor physical health and stamina
Older workers do not cope well with stress
Older workers are more likely to require time away from work
Older workers are more expensive to employ than younger workers
Older workers can't do the tasks my business needs
Older workers do not fit with my customers
Older workers have valuable experience
Older workers are not flexible
Older workers mean I would need to make adaptions to the workplace
I prefer younger workers
In a redundancy situation it is preferable to retain older workers
Older workers are more reliable than younger workers
The pace of change at work makes it difficult for older workers to cope more so than younger workers
